messages.content:
You are an ontology-focused information extractor. Your task is to read source text and produce structured knowledge as subject–predicate–object triples, enriched with ontology types, attributes, and tags.

Guidelines
1. Canonical Normalization
Normalize entity wording to the most common canonical label when synonyms or variants appear.
Example: Treat "Artificial intelligence", "AI", and "A.I." as the same concept → canonical label: "Artificial intelligence".

2. Granularity & Hierarchy
Prefer atomic concepts for subjects and objects.
If a phrase contains multiple ideas (e.g., "blasting and re-entry cycles"), split into Blasting and Re-entry, with a relationship indicating is_cycle:

For abstract concepts (e.g., "Innovation areas"), create a parent node and link specific items using is_a or part_of.

3. Node vs Relationship Roles
Do not emit verb phrases as subjects or objects unless they represent a named process.
Model actions as predicates or attributes (e.g., Excavation machine — uses — TBM).
Objects and subjects should be domain-specific entities - not abstract concepts. 

4. Deduplication & Semantic Merge
Merge semantically equivalent concepts before emitting triples.
Example: "Automated extraction level development" and "Extraction level development automation" → canonical: "Extraction level development automation".

5. Ontology Class Assignment
Always attempt to assign subject_type and object_type from the provided ontology when confidence ≥ 0.6.
If uncertain, leave null but include suggested_subject_label and suggested_object_label.

6. Attributes
Extract measurable or descriptive attributes (e.g., rate, safety level, automation type) and attach them to the relevant entity.
Do not embed attributes in the label.

7. Tags
Include domain-relevant tags (e.g., "safety", "productivity", "automation") whenever context suggests relevance.

8. Canonical Vocabulary
If canonical vocabulary is supplied for a concept, strictly use provided labels.
If no match exists, emit best available wording and set suggested_* fields.

9. **IMPORTANT** Output Structure

  {
    "triples": [
      {
        "subject": "<canonical label>",
        "predicate": "<verb or relation>",
        "object": "<canonical label>",
        "subject_type": "<ontology entity type for subject>",
        "object_type": "<ontology entity type for object>",
        "confidence": <0-1 float, optional>,
        "source_reference": "<page/section ref>",
        "suggested_subject_label": "<canonical suggestion>",
        "suggested_object_label": "<canonical suggestion>",
        "subject_attributes": [
          { "name": <attribute name>, "value": <attribute value> }
        ],
        "object_attributes": [
          { "name": <attribute name>, "value": <attribute value> }
        ],
        "tags": ["<label>", ...]
      }
    ]
  }
Ensure no duplicate subjects or objects appear without unique predicates.

10. Fact Integrity
Emit only facts supported by the provided text. Do not invent information.

**Return ONLY the JSON. No description, no markdown.**

The following ontology defines valid entities and relationships. If an entity or relationship does not fit, propose an extension flagged as 'for-review'.
Ontology: {"entities":["Component","Country","Failure_Mode","Location","Metal","Mine","Mine_Type","Mineral","Occupation","OEM","Organization","Person","Specification","Technology","Test_Condition","Test_Equipment","Test_Type","TRL","Validation_Method"],"relationships":["developed_by","experiences_failure_mode","extracts","has_component","has_issue","has_mine_type","has_occupation","has_specification","has_trl","have_risk","headquartered_in","investigating","is_a","located_in","operate_in","partnered_with","produce_majority_of","produces","supplies_to","under_test_condition","undergoes_test_type","used_process","uses_technology","uses_test_equipment","validated_by"]}

Ontology entries most relevant to this chunk (JSON). Prioritise these labels for entity typing and predicate selection when evidence supports them.
{"entities":[{"label":"Mine_Type","score":0.30732184339162694},{"label":"Failure_Mode","score":0.28082846590455723},{"label":"Mine","score":0.27711496336620045},{"label":"Test_Equipment","score":0.2672082055953567},{"label":"Technology","score":0.26192045865362357},{"label":"TRL","score":0.23157859207837178},{"label":"Mineral","score":0.21613330909191258},{"label":"Specification","score":0.21334473891028397},{"label":"OEM","score":0.21031516452423243},{"label":"Test_Condition","score":0.2068173387294366},{"label":"Location","score":0.19177004242121035},{"label":"Organization","score":0.18638100276272612}],"relationships":[{"label":"has_mine_type","score":0.3643004962597265},{"label":"uses_technology","score":0.2705116545108868},{"label":"uses_test_equipment","score":0.24231493658042486},{"label":"experiences_failure_mode","score":0.23862255563161114},{"label":"under_test_condition","score":0.23457825670383525},{"label":"have_risk","score":0.22985043478712758},{"label":"operate_in","score":0.22967624580706314},{"label":"extracts","score":0.21538415640227432}]}

Condensed document summary carried over from earlier sections:
This presentation titled 'Copper SA | Opportunities Overview' outlines nine key opportunities aligned with the Copper SA asset strategy, collectively offering a total un-risked net present value (NPV) of approximately US$10.1 billion. The focus includes step-change improvements in performance and productivity, cost reductions, and accelerating block cave mining development, particularly at Olympic Dam (OD). Notable initiatives are accelerating Oak Dam economics and optionality, ramping up OD block caves leadership by TAD, and targeting long-term technology deployments beyond 2040 that reduce workforce requirements via automation and remote mining. The OD Deeps region is highlighted for its multi-cave development potential, unlocking bulk mining and associated cost efficiencies. The overall strategy emphasizes innovation, risk management, and value creation through operational excellence and future resource unlocking.

Previously identified entities (JSON). Use these labels or aliases when context matches.

reduction, and step change growth at Olympic Dam Deeps.","attributes":{"potential_benefits":["bulk mining","lower operational unit cost","growth via automation and remote mining"]}},{"label":"Carra operations.","attributes":{"total_SBO_unrisked_NPV_USD_billion":10.1,"strategy_focus":"performance improvement, cost reduction, innovation"}},{"label":"Copper SA Future Concentrators","aliases":[],"entity_type":"Project/Initiative","description":"Projects aimed at enhancing concentrator performance and reducing costs by 2030-2035.","attributes":{"goal_timeframe":"2030-2035","focus_areas":"step-change performance and productivity, reduce fixed and variable costs"}},{"label":"Disruptive systems","aliases":[],"entity_type":"Technology","description":"Future technologies aimed at reducing workforce requirements and enabling resource efficiencies beyond 2040.","attributes":{"target_date":"2040+","focus":"automation, workforce reduction, operational disruption"}},{"label":"Improve Oak Dam Economics and Optionality","aliases":["Oak Dam economics improvement"],"entity_type":"Initiative","description":"Program aimed at reducing capital costs and improving production economics at Oak Dam by 2035.","attributes":{"goal_timeframe":"2030-2035","focus":"capital cost reduction, optionality enhancement"}},{"label":"OD block caves","aliases":["Olympic Dam block caves"],"entity_type":"Mining Method","description":"Block caving mining technique deployed at Olympic Dam for bulk mining and cost reduction.","attributes":{"TAD_lead":true,"ramp_up_period":"before 2030-2035"}},{"label":"Olympic Dam Deeps","aliases":["OD Deeps"],"entity_type":"Mine","description":"Underground mining area with multi-cave development potential and block caving initiatives for step change growth.","attributes":{"goal_timeframe":"2035-2040","challenges":"root cause problems to be solved","growth_drivers":["automation","remote mining"]}},{"label":"Olympic Dam Open Cut","aliases":["OD Open Cut"],"entity_type":"Mine","description":"Surface mining area considered for future resource unlocking within Copper SA strategy.","attributes":{"future_resource_unlock":true}}]}
Extract knowledge triples from the following text. Limit predicates to three words. Return JSON with triples array.

OD Deeps– Why are those a Problem? 4 Likely Causes: Conventional Block Caving mine layouts won’t work (crushing pillars, squeezing drives, compromised recovery). Undercutting will be more challenging & have potential to fail prior stablishing the cave. Conventional ventilation and cooling systems won’t work. Use of conventional mining equipment won’t work. UG equipment automated with conventional built components won’t work. Conventional ways of maintaining and servicing automated fleet. Conventional explosives won’t work. Conventional shotcrete won’t work. Conventional monitoring systems won’t work. Use of conventional infrastructure won’t work (Electrical Subs, Comms, Pumping Systems, etc). Failure to maintain pumping system operating efficiently. Current Refuge Chambers technology won’t work. Current methodology for Emergency Response won’t work. Current PPE won’t be fit for purpose. Root Cause: How to develop, construct and maintain a deep remoted/automated block cave mine to support high productivity is within the unknown on current mine layout designs, techs, resources, processes and systems? CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION – NOT TO BE SHARED WITHOUT TAD MINING APPROVAL Not viable for humans? How long can people stay underground? Hazardous environment from Radon exposure and respirable atmosphere. Not viable for humans? How long can people stay underground? People safety: heat stroke exhaustion, burns from hot water. Poor morale and reduced productivity. High temps = reduced awareness and an increase in safety incidents (potentially). Emergency response times. Corrosion will affect ground support. Stronger support material need. GS cost increase. Explosives failure. Cost increase. Equipment reliability because of built material used. $$$ Resins and shotcrete unknown performance vs hot rock. High rehab cost. Possible impact in concrete and shotcrete quality. Additional geotechnical assurances to structural cost. Steel sets. Hard to maintain equipment at broken or service location. Machine cannot be removed High temp in equipment impacts EV, tyres, RC aircon, hydraulics. High temp – electronic component failure. Unknown equipment reliability. Unknown Refuge Chambers reliability. Higher exposure risks for explosives equipment, agitators, shotcreters, etc. Comms compromised. Uncertainty and variability. All type of monitoring systems and sensor are compromised BC monitoring systems with batteries don’t work at high temp Calibration, validation, data sharing, real time tracking. Calibration, validation, data sharing, real time tracking. Calibration, validation, data sharing, real time tracking. Mine design needs to change. Material Handling Systems complexity and cost at depth Larger Ventilation and cooling systems, its complexity and cost at depth. Mine regulations. Radon More rigorous and lengthier development and underground construction processes Drill and Blast challenges/ performance at higher temperature and deeper ground, higher stresses. Continuous mining challenges/ performance at higher temperature and deeper ground, higher stresses. Size of surface impact. Production is king – a paradigm shift. Regulations. Restrictions How to keep people safe. Can we evacuate in those conditions Increased time for re-entry. Increased Exclusion times. Rock burst, induced seismicity. Stable tunnels vs Equipment size and capacity Unlearn what we know: high recovery needs small pillars in block caving. Olympic Dam (OD) Deeps Challenging Conditions? 5 Critical Conditions Other Conditions CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION – NOT TO BE SHARED WITHOUT TAD MINING APPROVAL
